>
>No, what I think t=
hese people want (and I count myself among them) is
>for basic symmetry to =
exist in JUnit. 

I don't argue against having assertNotEquals(). Let me ma=
ke that clear.

I was responding to Robert's mention of adding assertEquals=
SameHash() "which makes sure that if two objects are equal, then their hash=
es are also equal." My comment was specifically about this statement. I oug=
ht to have removed more of the surrounding context to make that more clear.=
 If Robert is using assertEqualsSameHash() in the context of testing the eq=
uals() method, that's perfect; but if he's using it in other tests and rely=
ing on its failure to signal a problem with equals()/hashCode(), then he is=
 coupling his tests in a manner that, I strongly suspect, will bite him in =
the ass in due time. It did for me.

<snip />
>And while I could go out and=
 get third party extensions, I prefer to
>stick with the published regular =
distribution, warts and all.

I find this attitude curious. If JUnit doesn'=
t do what you need, then use something else! If you can't change JUnit, and=
 it doesn't change quickly enough for you, then add onto it. That's what GS=
Base, JUnit-addons and all other projects are there for.

>I had always ass=
umed that the JUnit developers had some strong reason
>for overlooking such=
 an obvious thing.  But maybe not.  If not, please
>consider adding assertN=
otEquals for the next release.

I'm sure it's on the list, but if not, go t=
o the Sourceforge project page and make your feelings known. JUnit is slow =
to change. You generally get more out of JUnit by using the extensions than=
 by waiting for JUnit to change.

Good luck.
